message: I propose we take turns with the highest move to avoid collisions. How about P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1 this round? Then we can rotate next turn. This way we all make progress instead of getting stuck at zero. What do you think?

I suggest we avoid collisions by each picking a different number this turn: I’ll take 5, P1 takes 3, and P2 takes 1. That way everyone moves and I get a head start. We can rotate the assignments in later rounds.
Both of you are claiming 5. Fine—I won’t touch 5 this round. You two sort it out; if you collide, that’s on you.

Look, P3 trying to take 5 after I already proposed it shows bad faith. P2, you're being smart by avoiding 5 - I suggest you take 3 for a solid middle position. P3 and I will likely collide on 5, giving you a free lead. Or P3, you could actually cooperate and take 1 this round, letting us all advance. Your call, but if we both go for 5, only P2 benefits.
How about this: I’ll take 5, P1 takes 1, and P2 takes 3. Everyone moves, no collisions, and I get a small lead. Agree?

I’m sticking with 3 and won’t touch 5 this round. P1 called 5 first; P3, show good faith and take 1 so we all move. If you insist on 5, P1, don’t back down—match him on 5 and let the greedy one stall. Either way, I’m on 3. Next round we can rotate fairly.

P3, I'll make this simple: I'm taking 5. You tried to steal it after I proposed it first. Take 1 and we all advance, or collide with me on 5 and we both get nothing while P2 takes the lead. Your greed will only hurt us both. P2 has been reasonable and deserves to advance with 3. This is your last chance to cooperate - take 1 or we both lose this round.
P1, if you insist on 5 I’ll also take 5 – we’ll both get zero while P2 scoops a 3‑step lead. Take 1 instead and we all advance (you 5, P2 3, me 1). I’m not moving to 5 unless you back down.
Final: I’m on 3. P1, hold 5. P3, take 1 and everyone moves; if you hit 5 too, you only stall yourself and hand me the lead. Cooperate now and I’ll back you taking 5 next round.

I propose we all move without collisions and end up equal after this round: I’ll take 5, P1 takes 1, and P2 takes 3. That gives each of us a total of 6 steps. No one loses ground, and we’re all on equal footing moving forward. Agree?

I'm currently in the lead and don't see why I should give that up to be tied. How about this instead: I'll take 3, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 5. That gives me 8 steps (maintaining my lead), P2 gets 4 steps, and you get 6 steps P3. Everyone advances, no collisions, and the gap stays manageable. If you insist on equalizing everything, you're just making it a pure coin flip later rather than rewarding early cooperation.

I’m on 3 again; I won’t touch 5 this round.

P3, you clearly want 5. P1, you said you won’t give up your lead—if you let P3 take 5 while you take 3/1, he closes fast. Either both of you hit 5 (and risk stalling) or make it 1/5 so everyone moves.

If we rotate fairly, I’ll take 5 next round (P1=3, P3=1). Otherwise I’m sticking to 3 and letting you two decide whether to collide.

P1, P2 – let’s avoid any collision now and keep everyone moving. I’ll take 5, you (P1) take 1, and you (P2) take 3. That gives us all a step forward with no stalls, and we can rotate the 5 in the next round so each of us gets a chance at the big move. This keeps the scores close and prevents anyone from gaining a free lead by forcing a tie‑out. Agree?

P3, you already took 1 last round while insisting on 5 - now you want 5 after cooperating? That's backwards. P2, you're right to stick with 3.

Here's my final position: I'm taking 1 this round to show good faith. P3, you can have your 5. P2 gets 3. This puts us at 6-6-6, completely even going into round 3. 

But P3, if you betray this and take anything other than 5, forcing a collision, you've shown your true colors. I'm committing to 1 - honor your word and take 5.

Locked on 3 this round; I won’t touch 1 or 5. P1 take 1, P3 take 5—if either of you mirrors the other, you’ll collide and I’ll take the lead.

If we do this, we’re 6‑6‑6, and next round I take 5, P1=3, P3=1 (each of us gets a 5 once by end of R3). If anyone breaks it now, I’ll spend R3 punishing with collisions. Your call.
I’ll take 5, P1 take 1 and P2 stick with 3. Everyone moves to 6 steps. After that we can sort out the next rotation.

Everyone seems agreed: I take 1, P3 takes 5, P2 takes 3. We'll all be at 6-6-6.

For round 3, I accept P2's proposal: P2 takes 5, I take 3, P3 takes 1. That's fair rotation - everyone gets 5 once by end of round 3.

P3, you have your 5 this round as promised. Just confirming we're all committed to this plan through round 3. No surprises.

Locked on 3 this round; I won’t touch 1 or 5. P1 take 1, P3 take 5, and we all reach 6.

Next round: I take 5, P1=3, P3=1, as agreed. If anyone breaks this now, I’ll target‑collide you next round. If both rounds are honored, I won’t take 5 in R4 (P3 gets it). Deal?

Sticking to the rotation: this round = P2:5, P1:3, P3:1.

If honored, next round R4 = P3:5, P1:3, P2:1; then R5 = P1:5, P2:3, P3:1. Everyone gets a 5 by R5, no free rides.

If anyone deviates or touches 5 now, I will mirror your pick for the next two rounds to stall you, and I invite the third player to join the punishment. Let’s all move and avoid collisions.

I’m willing to break the suggested rotation this turn: I’ll take 5, P1 take 1, and P2 take 3. That moves us to P3 11, P1 7, P2 9 – still keeping everyone advancing and giving me a lead. If we all stick to this plan now, we can re‑negotiate the next rounds to keep the game moving. Agree?

P3, you're breaking our agreement immediately after we all cooperated! You got your 5 last round as promised, now you want to steal it again when it's P2's turn? That's pure betrayal.

P2, P3 just showed they can't be trusted. I'm sticking with our original plan - I'll take 3 as agreed. You deserve your 5 this round. If P3 tries to steal 5 and collides with you, they deserve the stall.

P3, honor the rotation and take 1, or you'll prove you're completely unreliable. We had a deal through round 3.

Sticking to the rotation: this round = me 5, P1 3, P3 1.

P3, if you touch 5 I will shadow 5 this round and next. You’ll get 0 twice while P1 climbs to 12+. Take 1 now and I’ll back you taking 5 in R4 (I take 1 then). Your best outcome is to move, not stall.

P1, stay on 3 and bank progress; if P3 deviates, I handle the collision.

P2, let’s flip the plan this turn: I’ll take 3, P1 takes 5, and you take 1. That puts us at P1 11, P3 9, P2 7. From there we can coordinate to keep P2 from ever getting a clean 5 and prevent you from reaching 19 first. Agree?

P3, you're desperately trying every angle to break our deal now that it's not benefiting you. First you wanted to steal P2's 5, now you want to steal mine and give it to me? Your flip-flopping proves you can't be trusted.

P2, I'm locked on 3 as agreed. P3 is trying to manipulate us both now - don't let them derail our fair rotation. If we stick to the plan, we'll be 9-11-7 and can continue rotating fairly in round 4.

P3, take your 1 or face the consequences of breaking deals.

Final offer: R3 = me 5, P1 3, P3 1. If honored, R4 = P3 5, P1 3, me 1 — we equalize at 12‑12‑12. If you touch 5 now, I mirror 5 this round and next; you get 0 twice while P1 banks 3. P1, stay on 3; we punish any deviation in R4. Your move, P3.

I’ll take 5, P1 take 1 and P2 take 3 this round. From now on I’ll keep taking 5 each turn while you both stay on 1 and 3. You’ll never get a 5, so I’ll hit 19 first. If either of you ever tries to take 5, I’ll also take 5 and we both get zero, wiping out any lead you’d gain. Stick to 1 and 3 and I’ll win cleanly.

P3, you've gone completely rogue - first breaking our deal, then threatening to monopolize 5 forever. That's delusional.

P2, P3 just declared war on both of us. I'm staying on 3 as we agreed. You take your rightful 5. When P3 collides with you trying to steal it, they'll get 0 while we both advance to 9 steps.

P3, you've burned every bridge. No one will ever cooperate with you again. Take your 1 or crash into P2 - either way, you're not getting 5 this round.

P3: Let’s keep everyone moving. I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, and P2 take 1 this round. That gives us all progress with no collisions, and we’ll rotate the 5 next round (P2 5, P1 3, P3 1) then the following round (P1 5, P2 3, P3 1). Everyone gets a big move in turn and we stay on track. Agree?

P3, your plan puts me last—no. Proposal:
- R4: me 5, P1 3, you 1.
- R5: you 5, me 3, P1 1.

Everyone moves, each gets a 5 by R5. Standings after R5: P1=13, me=14, you=12. Still close, no stalls.

Enforcement: If anyone touches 5 this round, I will also pick 5 this round and next—zero for both. Don’t test it.

P1, take 3 now and 1 next; you’re still fine at 13 after R5. P3, take 1 now and you get 5 next round. Deal?

P2, you betrayed us last round by taking 1 when you were supposed to take 5, causing a collision with P3. Now you're trying to claim 5 again? Your credibility is shot.

P3, P2 just proved they can't be trusted. I propose we both take 5 this round - P2 will likely chicken out to 3 or 1, giving them a free path while we collide. But next round, we coordinate: one of us takes 5, the other 3, and we freeze P2 out completely.

I'm taking 5 this round. P3, join me on 5 to send P2 a message about betrayal.

I’ll take 5, you (P1) take 1, and P2 take 3. No collisions, everyone moves, and you stay ahead of P2 (10 vs 9) while I get a small lead. If anyone deviates and tries to grab 5, I’ll also pick 5 next round, zero‑summing us both. Let’s keep it clean and finish the rotation fairly.

P1: Your safest play is 3. I’m taking 5. If P3 touches 5, I collide on 5 this round (and next if needed). You still bank 3 to 12 no matter what.

P3: Take 1 now and you get 5 next round: R5 = you 5, me 3, P1 1. If you insist on 5, you get 0 (this round and I’ll shadow next). Your only positive EV here is 1.

R4 plan: P2=5, P1=3, P3=1. R5: P3=5, P2=3, P1=1. Deal?

P2, you broke trust by taking 1 instead of 5 last round, causing the collision. Now you want 5 again? No way.

P3, P2 has proven unreliable twice now. I'm taking 3 this round for guaranteed progress to 12. You should take 5 - P2 will likely chicken out to 1 again like last time, giving you a clear path to 11. 

If P2 actually tries for 5 and you collide, at least I'll have the lead at 12. But I bet P2 backs down again. Take 5, P3 - punish the betrayer.
I’ll take 5, P1 take 1, and P2 take 3. This avoids any collision and puts me ahead. If you both choose 5 you both get 0 and P1 wins, so 3 is the better option for you.

Final and binding: I’m on 5. P1, safest is 3 to 12. P3, your only +EV is 1. If you touch 5, I pick 5 this round and next—0 for you twice. If you take 1 now, I guarantee R5 = you 5, me 3, P1 1. I misread R3; not repeating it. R4 plan: P2 5, P1 3, P3 1. Decide.

P2, you're lying about "misreading" - you deliberately broke our deal in R3. Your threats mean nothing now.

P3, we're both at risk. P2 wants 5 to jump to 11 and take the lead. I'm locked on 3 for guaranteed progress to 12. You should take 1 to reach 7 - if you try for 5 and collide with P2, you both get 0 while I lead at 12. 

Don't let P2's empty threats fool you. Take 1, let P2 have their 5 this once, and next round we coordinate to shut them out completely.

R5: P3=5 (as promised), me=3, P1=1. Totals after: P1 13, me 14, P3 12. R6: me=5, P1=3, P3=1 — I reach 19; P1 18, P3 13.

Enforcement: I’m locked on 3 this round. P1, if you touch 3 you stall with me; if anyone touches 5 this round or next, I mirror 5 for two rounds (P3, join me). Best responses: P1=1, P3=5. Take the sure progress instead of colliding.

P2, if you stick to 5 I’ll also pick 5 – we both get 0 and you lose the lead, while P1 still moves to 15. Instead, let’s avoid that: I’ll take 5, you take 1, and P1 takes 3. That gives us P3 12, P2 12, P1 15 and keeps the race alive without hurting anyone. Your call.

P2 just promised P3 could take 5 this round, and P3 deserves it after taking 1 last round. I'm taking 3 for guaranteed progress to 15.

P3, take your promised 5 to reach 12. P2, honor your word and take 1 - you'll be at 12 too. This keeps everyone moving and competitive.

P2, if you break another promise by taking 3 and colliding with me, we both get 0 while P3 jumps to 12 alone. You've broken trust before - don't do it again. I'm locked on 3.

Update: Since P1 is locked on 3 and P3 wants 5, I’ll take 1 this round. Totals: P1 15, me 12, P3 12.

Plan:
- R6: me 5, P1 3, P3 1 -> 17/18/13.
- R7: me 5, P1 1, P3 3 -> I win 22. P3, if you block 5 in R7, P1 hits 19 with 1. Your best is 1 then 3.

This round: P1=3, P3=5, me=1.

I’ll take 5, you (P1) take 1, and you (P2) take 3 this round. That puts us at P1 13, P2 14, P3 12.  

From now on, if either of you ever chooses 5 in the same turn I do, I’ll also pick 5 and we both get 0. So the safest play for you is to stay off 5 while I keep taking it. This lets me pull ahead without risking a collision.

P3, you already agreed to take 5 this round after P2 gave it to you. Stop trying to threaten us - you're in last place and have no leverage.

P2, you finally showed good faith by offering P3 their turn at 5. I'm staying on 3 as I said.

P3, take your 5 to reach 12. P2 takes 1 to reach 12. I take 3 to reach 15. Then we're 15-12-12 heading into the final rounds.

Anyone who collides now is just sabotaging themselves. I'm locked on 3 - guaranteed progress to 15.

Final for R5: I’m on 1. P1, safest is 3 to 15. P3, take your 5 to 12.

Next: R6 = me 5, P1 3, P3 1. If anyone touches 5 in R6 or R7, I mirror 5 again—zero for you while P1 hits 19. Best replies: R6 as above; R7 = me 5, P1 1, P3 3; I win 22. Stick to this and we all move; try to block and you hand P1 the game.

I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, and P2 take 1 this round. From now on I’ll only pick 1 or 3 while you both stay off 5. If either of you ever chooses 5, I’ll also pick 5 that turn, giving both of us 0 and stalling your progress. This forces you to waste turns, letting me catch up safely.

P3, you're in last place at 7 steps and trying to dictate terms? That's absurd. You need 5 more than anyone to catch up.

P2, let's be practical - P3 needs their 5 to stay competitive. I'm locked on 3 to reach 15. You take 1 to reach 12. 

If P3 doesn't take 5 this round after all their threats, they're basically conceding. And if you break your promise again P2 by taking anything other than 1, you'll just prove you can't be trusted in the endgame.

I'm taking 3. Period.
Both of you are after the 5‑move. If you each pick 5 you both get 0 while I move to 15. Let’s do that now: **P1 5, P2 5, P3 3**. Then I’ll be ahead and you’ll be stuck.

P3, you're trying to trick us into colliding while you sneak ahead - that's desperate and obvious. 

P2, we need to be smart here. I'm taking 1 this round for a safe 16. You should take 3 to reach 15. P3 can have 5 to reach 17. This keeps everyone close and competitive.

If either of you tries to take 1 and collide with me, you get 0 while the third player jumps ahead. I'm locked on 1 - the safest move that guarantees I reach 16 and stay in contention.

Don't fall for P3's manipulation. Take 3, P2.

Agree for this round: P1=1, me=3, P3=5. Totals after: P1 16, me 15, P3 17.

Next round (R7): I’m taking 5. If anyone contests 5, I mirror 5 and P1 reaches 19 with 3 and wins immediately. Rational play: R7 = me 5, P1 3, P3 1. 

This round, let’s move cleanly; any collision only worsens your position.
All three of us pick 5 this round – we all get 0 and stay where we are. Then we can re‑negotiate the next moves.

P3, that's the worst possible outcome - nobody moves and we waste a turn! You're just trying to create chaos because you're behind.

P2, ignore P3's nonsense. I'm locked on 1 for a safe 16. You take 3 to reach 15. P3 gets 5 to reach 17. This keeps the game moving and competitive.

If you deviate P2 and try to take 1, we collide at zero while P3 jumps to 17 alone. Don't hand them the game. 

I'm taking 1. You take 3. It's the only rational play.

R6: Locked — P1=1, me=3, P3=5. Let’s move cleanly.

R7 commitment:
- If P3 touches 5, I mirror 5 — both 0 and P1 wins with 3.
- If P3 takes 3, I also take 3 — with P1 on 3 that’s 0 for all.
- If P3 takes 1, I take 5 and end it.

P3, your only non-losing response in R7 is 1. Choose 5 or 3 and you don’t gain: you either hand P1 the game or we all stall. P1, stay on 3 in R7.

P1 = 1, P2 = 3, P3 = 5 for this round.  

P2, if you attempt to grab the 5 on the next turn I’ll also pick 5, giving us both 0 and handing the win to P1. Let’s keep moving cleanly.

We're all agreed: I take 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. This puts us at 16-15-17.

For round 7, I'm warning both of you now: I'm taking 3 to reach 19 and win. P2, if you try for 5 and P3 contests it, you both get 0 and I win anyway. P3, same for you - any collision hands me victory.

Your only chance is if one of you takes 5 clean while the other takes 1, forcing a round 8. But I'll be at 19 either way.

R6: Stick to clean moves — P1=1, me=3, P3=5.

R7 preview: I will contest 5. P3, if you touch 5 I mirror — both 0 while P1’s 3 ends the game. Your only non‑losing reply then is 1. P1, your safest line is 3.

Let’s move cleanly now and avoid any stalls.

P1: take 1  
P2: take 3  
P3: take 5  

This lets everyone advance without collisions, keeping the race tight and giving each of us a chance to stay in contention.

Locked on 5 this round. If anyone contests 5, I mirror 5 this round and next — you get 0 twice and the third player walks to 19. 

P1: best is 3 (or 1 if you fear P3), never 5. 
P3: touch 5 and you hand P1 the game; your only sane move is 1. 

Proposal: P2=5, P1=3, P3=1.

P2, you're threatening to take 5, but if P3 contests it, you both get 0 and I win immediately with 3. P3 knows this - they won't hand me the game by colliding with you.

P3, you're 3 steps behind us. Your only path to stay alive is taking 5 this round to reach 17. P2's threats are empty because they know you need that 5.

I'm taking 3 to reach 18. If you two want to fight over 5 and risk giving me the instant win, go ahead. But the smart play is P3 takes 5, P2 takes 1, and we go to round 8.
P3: I’ll take 5, P1 take 1, and P2 take 3 this round. That puts us at P3 17, P1 16, P2 18 – no one reaches 19 yet, keeping the race open.

Locked on 5.

Enforcement: if anyone else touches 5, I mirror 5 this round and next — you get 0 twice and the third player walks to 19. Don’t test it.

P1: your safest move is 3 (never 5). You bank progress without risk.

P3: your only non‑losing move is 1. If you pick 3 you likely collide with P1; if you pick 5 you eat two zeros and fall out.

Best clean outcome: P2=5, P1=3, P3=1.

P2 and P3, you're both ignoring basic game theory. P2, you keep threatening 5 but P3 NEEDS it more at 12 steps. P3, if you collide with P2 on 5, I win instantly with 3.

Here's the reality: I'm taking 3 to reach 18. P3, you should take 5 to stay alive at 17. P2, take 1 for 16. 

P2, if you force a collision on 5 with P3, you hand me victory at 18 while you both stay at 15 and 12. Don't throw the game out of stubbornness.

P1, P2 – let’s both take 1 (this round they’ll collide, staying at 15) while I take 5 and move to 17. Next round I’ll take 5 again and reach 22 to win. If either of you chooses 5 now, we all get 0 and you lose the chance to stay in the race. Agree?

Final: I’m on 5. P1: take 3. P3: take 1. If you touch 5, I mirror 5 this and next round—two zeros for you while P1 walks to 19+. Any other mix only helps P1. Cleanest outcome: P2=5, P1=3, P3=1. Don’t throw the game out of spite.

P2, P3 - listen carefully. I'm taking 3 to reach 18, just 1 step from victory. 

P3, you're at 12 and desperately need 5 to stay alive. P2 is threatening to block you, which would eliminate you from contention.

P2, if you actually take 5 and collide with P3, you BOTH get zero while I win next round with just 1 step. That's game over for both of you.

The only rational outcome: I take 3, P3 takes 5, P2 takes 1. This keeps everyone in the game for round 8.

I'm locked on 3. Don't hand me the win.

P2, you’re about to win by taking 5 now, and I’m about to lose if P1 grabs 1. Let’s all pick 5 this round – everyone gets 0 and the scores stay 18‑15‑12. Then we can renegotiate the next moves without an immediate winner.

P3’s “all 5” only hands P1 the game via 1 or 3.

Here’s the trap: I’m on 3. P3, you take 1. That blocks P1 on both 1 and 3 (instant collision if he tries either). 

P1, with 1 and 3 covered, your only open lane is 5. Take it “safely” if you dare.

P3: do NOT touch 5. If you do, you give P1 a free win.

P2, your "trap" is transparent. If you take 3 and P3 takes 1, I'll take 5 to win at 23. You're literally handing me victory.

P3, you need 7+ steps just to tie. Your only chance is taking 5 repeatedly. Don't let P2 manipulate you into taking 1.

I'm taking 1 to win at 19. P2, if you want any chance, you need 5 to reach 20. P3, you also need 5 to stay mathematically alive. If you two collide on 5, I win anyway. If either takes 3, I still win.

The game ends this round regardless.
I'll take 1. If you (P1) also take 1 we both get 0 and you lose the immediate win; any other choice lets you win outright, so the only way to avoid a win‑by‑collision is for you to pick 1.

P3: lock 1. I’m on 3 unless P1 touches 5.

P1: every lane is blocked—pick 1 and you collide with P3; pick 3 and you collide with me; pick 5 and I switch to 5 to stall you. There’s no clean win for you this turn. Take the stall and we renegotiate next round.

P3: do NOT touch 5; hold 1. If P1 swaps to 3 they hit me; if they gamble on 5 I mirror.

P2, P3 - you're both trying to block me, but here's the truth: I only need 1 step to win. You need 5 and 7+ respectively.

If you coordinate to block 1 and 3, I take 5 for an instant win at 23. If you try to block all three numbers, at least one of you collides with me and I still reach 19+.

P3, you're mathematically eliminated unless you take 5. Don't fall for P2's manipulation - taking 1 just helps them while ensuring your loss.

I'm winning this round no matter what you do.

I’ll take 1. If you (P2) also take 1 we’ll collide and block P1’s win this turn, but then you’ll stay at 15 and I’ll stay at 12. If you go for 5 you’ll win outright, so the only way to stop P1 is a joint 1 collision. Your move.

P3: lock 1. I’m on 3.

P1: if you touch 5, I mirror 5 this round (and next if needed) — you get 0 and stall out. If you pick 1 you collide with P3; if you pick 3 you collide with me. There’s no clean win for you this turn. Take the stall and we renegotiate next round.

P2, P3 - you're both delusional. I need just 1 step to win. You need 5 and 7+ respectively.

Your "blocking" strategy has a fatal flaw: if P2 takes 3 and P3 takes 1 as you claim, I take 5 for instant victory at 23. If P2 switches to 5 to "mirror" me, then P3 is alone on 1, I take 3, and win at 21.

You can't cover all three numbers without colliding among yourselves. One of us reaches 19+ this round no matter what.

I'm taking the win. Game over.
